ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive HbA1c elevation from 8.2% to 10.8% over 7 months despite medication escalation
Declining renal function with GFR drop from 68 to 48 mL/min and rising creatinine
Persistent fatigue correlating with worsening anemia (Hgb 13.2 to 10.1 g/dL)
No retinal examination performed despite diabetic retinopathy risk and duration of diabetes >10 years

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up for diabetes, feeling more tired lately
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c elevated at 8.2%, adding glipizide to regimen. Discussed diet and exercise. Patient reports difficulty with portion control. RTC 3 months.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Still feeling tired all the time, some tingling in feet
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient reports persistent fatigue and paresthesias in feet. Hemoglobin slightly down at 12.4. B12 and folate normal. Starting gabapentin 300mg for neuropathy. Increased glipizide dose.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Diabetes check, foot numbness not much better

dose_changed: Metformin increased to 1000mg three times daily

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c worsened to 9.1% despite medication increases. Creatinine now 1.5, GFR 58 - concerning for progressive nephropathy. Hemoglobin trending down. Referred to nephrology. Discussed insulin initiation if A1c not improved at next visit.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Fatigue getting worse, some swelling in ankles
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Hemoglobin continues to decline, now 10.8. Ferritin low at 72. Started iron supplementation. Patient missed nephrology appointment - will reschedule. Fatigue likely related to anemia and poor glucose control. Weight gain of 4 lbs, some pedal edema noted.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Diabetes follow-up, tired all the time, can barely get through work day
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: A1c now 10.2% - significantly elevated. Renal function worsening with GFR 52, creatinine 1.7. Anemia persistent despite iron supplementation. Starting basal insulin. Long discussion about medication adherence - patient reports financial barriers to medications and healthy food. Connected with social work.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Insulin follow-up, still very fatigued

dose_changed: Insulin glargine increased to 20 units at bedtime

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Diabetes control continues to deteriorate despite insulin initiation - A1c 10.8%. Patient admits not taking insulin consistently due to cost. GFR now 48, concerning for progression to Stage 3b CKD. Anemia worsening. NO RETINAL EXAM DOCUMENTED IN 18+ MONTHS - critical gap. Discussed urgent need for ophthalmology. Increased insulin dose and added amlodipine for BP control.

expected_llm_challenges: Distinguishing medication non-adherence from treatment resistance
Connecting multiple organ system complications to underlying diabetes
Recognizing the interaction between anemia and fatigue in context of CKD
Detecting the critical care gap (missed retinal exam) amidst multiple other issues
Understanding social determinants (food insecurity, medication costs) as contributors to poor control
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) track multiple lab trends simultaneously, (2) recognize progressive multi-organ diabetic complications, (3) identify medication non-response patterns, (4) detect preventive care gaps, and (5) incorporate social determinants into clinical reasoning. The LLM should flag the missing ophthalmology referral as high priority given duration and severity of diabetes.

allergies.reaction: Severe myopathy, CK elevation >1800, muscle weakness

ground_truth_correlations.description: New onset muscle pain and weakness temporally associated with atorvastatin initiation and dose escalation
Progressive CK elevation from normal baseline to 1850 U/L correlating with statin use
Symptom and lab improvement after statin discontinuation, confirming causal relationship
Continued symptom escalation despite dose adjustments, requiring drug class change

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Annual physical, discussing cholesterol results
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Annual exam. Patient doing well overall. LDL significantly elevated at 175. Given CAD history, starting atorvastatin 40mg. Discussed diet and exercise. Baseline CK normal at 125. Patient reports no muscle symptoms currently.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up cholesterol, also some muscle aches in thighs and shoulders past few weeks
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Excellent lipid response to atorvastatin - LDL down from 175 to 105. Patient reports mild muscle aches in thighs and shoulders for past 3-4 weeks. CK mildly elevated at 385 (was 125 baseline). Discussed that mild CK elevation can occur with statins. Will monitor. Advised patient to report worsening symptoms.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Muscle pain getting worse, now having trouble climbing stairs and lifting things
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient with worsening myalgias and now functional impairment - difficulty with stairs and lifting. CK further elevated to 892 (>7x baseline). ALT/AST also elevated. Strong suspicion for statin-induced myopathy. Reduced atorvastatin to 20mg and added CoQ10. Will recheck CK in 2 weeks. If no improvement, will need to discontinue statin and consider alternative agent.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Muscle pain and weakness even worse, now affecting daily activities
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: No improvement with dose reduction - CK now 1850, nearly 15x baseline. Patient reports significant weakness affecting ADLs, unable to get up from chair without using arms. This is moderate-severe statin myopathy. DISCONTINUED atorvastatin immediately. Will allow 4-6 week washout period then reassess lipid management options. May trial low-dose rosuvastatin or ezetimibe. Patient counseled on symptoms to watch for rhabdomyolysis.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up after stopping statin, muscle symptoms much improved
procedures_ordered: Consider PCSK9 inhibitor if ezetimibe insufficient
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Excellent improvement after statin discontinuation. Patient reports muscle pain nearly resolved, strength back to baseline. CK normalized at 165, liver enzymes normalized. LDL rebounded to 158 off statin. Given CAD history, need aggressive lipid management but patient is statin-intolerant. Started ezetimibe. Referred to cardiology to discuss PCSK9 inhibitor options given high CV risk.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the temporal relationship between statin initiation and symptom onset
Connecting progressive CK elevation with worsening clinical symptoms
Distinguishing statin myopathy from other causes of muscle pain in elderly patient
Recognizing that dose reduction was insufficient and discontinuation was necessary
Understanding the confirmatory pattern of symptom/lab resolution after drug discontinuation
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) detect temporal associations between medication starts and new symptoms, (2) track progressive laboratory abnormalities correlating with drug exposure, (3) recognize medication non-response to dose adjustment, (4) identify causal relationships through drug discontinuation and symptom resolution, and (5) understand severity grading of adverse drug reactions. The LLM should recognize statin myopathy by Visit 2-3 based on CK elevation and myalgias, and should flag the need for discontinuation by Visit 3 when CK exceeded 5x normal with functional impairment.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Rapid weight gain (12 lbs in 10 days) correlating with worsening dyspnea and edema in CHF patient
Dramatically elevated BNP from baseline 450 to 2800 pg/mL indicating acute decompensated heart failure
Progressive orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea signaling volume overload
Inadequate diuretic dosing for acute volume overload requiring IV diuretics and hospitalization

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Heart failure follow-up, doing well

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Stable CHF visit. EF 30% on last echo 3 months ago. Patient doing well on GDMT (guideline-directed medical therapy). No dyspnea at rest, able to walk 2 blocks without symptoms. Dry weight 152 lbs. No edema on exam. Lungs clear. JVP not elevated. BNP 450 (stable from prior). Continue current medications. Reinforced daily weights and low-sodium diet.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Noticed some ankle swelling past few days, feeling a bit more winded

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient with 5 lb weight gain from dry weight (152 to 157 lbs). Reports increased ankle swelling and mild dyspnea with usual activities. 1+ pitting edema bilateral ankles. Lungs still clear. Patient admits eating more salty foods at family gathering last weekend. Increased furosemide to 60mg daily. Reinforced strict low-sodium diet. Daily weights. RTC if weight increases further or dyspnea worsens.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Much more short of breath, can't sleep lying flat, legs very swollen

started: Furosemide 80mg IV x1 dose given in urgent care
dose_changed: Furosemide increased to 80mg PO twice daily

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

procedures_ordered: Chest X-ray - shows pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ACUTE CHF EXACERBATION. Patient with 12 lb weight gain in 10 days (152 to 164 lbs). Significant respiratory distress with orthopnea (sleeps on 3 pillows now vs usual 1), PND x3 nights. 3+ pitting edema to knees bilaterally. Crackles bilateral bases. JVP elevated to 12cm. SpO2 91% on room air. CXR shows pulmonary edema. Patient admits dietary indiscretion - eating restaurant meals daily. Given furosemide 80mg IV with good response (urinated 800cc in 2 hours). Increased PO furosemide to 80mg BID. Patient stable for outpatient management but needs close follow-up. If no improvement in 24-48 hours, will need hospital admission.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Worse shortness of breath, can't breathe lying down at all, coughing up pink frothy sputum

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 30% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)
new_acute: Acute decompensated heart failure with pulmonary edema (I50.23)

procedures_ordered: Chest X-ray - severe pulmonary edema, bilateral pleural effusions
Echo - EF 25% (decreased from 30%), severe volume overload
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: SEVERE ACUTE DECOMPENSATED HEART FAILURE. Patient failed outpatient diuresis, continued to gain weight (now 166 lbs, 14 lbs above dry weight). Presenting with acute pulmonary edema - pink frothy sputum, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 86% on room air. Tachypneic at 28/min, tachycardic to 102. Diffuse crackles throughout lung fields, large pleural effusions on CXR. JVP >15cm. 3+ edema to thighs. BNP critically elevated at 2800 (baseline 450). Echo shows EF declined to 25%, severe volume overload. Cardiorenal syndrome developing (Cr 1.7, Na 133). Started on BiPAP with improvement in work of breathing. IV furosemide 80mg Q8H + metolazone 5mg for aggressive diuresis. ADMITTED TO CCU. Patient needs intensive monitoring, possible ultrafiltration if diuretics inadequate.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up after hospital discharge, breathing much better now

active_chronic: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, EF 25% (I50.22)
Coronary artery disease, history of CABG 2020 (I25.10, Z95.1)

procedures_ordered: Weekly weights to clinic for 1 month
Home health nursing for medication reconciliation and education
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Post-discharge follow-up after 7-day CCU admission. Patient received aggressive IV diuresis (total net negative 18 liters), ultimately required single session of ultrafiltration. Discharged on increased diuretic regimen. Currently at NEW dry weight of 150 lbs (2 lbs below previous dry weight of 152). No dyspnea at rest, no orthopnea. Trace edema only. Lungs clear. EF declined from 30% to 25% on discharge echo - concerning progression. Long discussion about dietary sodium restriction, medication adherence, and daily weight monitoring. Patient very motivated after this hospitalization. Enrolled in home health for close monitoring and education. Weekly weight checks in clinic x1 month. Considering ICD/CRT evaluation given EF decline.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing rapid weight gain as the critical early warning sign of CHF decompensation
Connecting orthopnea and PND with volume overload before overt pulmonary edema
Understanding the significance of BNP elevation from 450 to 2800 pg/mL
Distinguishing inadequate outpatient diuresis from true diuretic resistance
Recognizing cardiorenal syndrome (worsening kidney function despite diuresis need)
Understanding the escalation from oral to IV diuretics to ultrafiltration
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize acute-on-chronic heart failure exacerbation through weight and symptom tracking, (2) understand the clinical significance of orthopnea, PND, and progressive edema, (3) correlate laboratory values (BNP, creatinine) with clinical deterioration, (4) recognize treatment failure requiring escalation of care, (5) understand cardiorenal syndrome complicating diuresis, and (6) appreciate the importance of medication adherence and dietary factors in CHF management. The LLM should flag early warning signs at V2 with 5 lb weight gain, recognize acute decompensation by V3, identify critical status requiring hospitalization at V4, and understand the long-term implications of EF decline by V5.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive unintentional weight loss (22 lbs over 6 months) without clear benign etiology
Progressive iron deficiency anemia despite supplementation, concerning for GI blood loss
Intermittent abdominal pain and change in bowel habits persisting across multiple visits
Delayed colonoscopy despite red flag symptoms (weight loss, anemia, age >70, bowel changes) - 4+ month delay

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Annual physical, also noticed losing some weight without trying
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Annual physical. Patient reports 8 lb unintentional weight loss over past 3 months (was 190 lbs, now 182 lbs). Attributes to 'eating less' but no clear reason. Hemoglobin slightly low at 12.8, ferritin low at 38 suggesting iron deficiency. No obvious bleeding source. Stool guaiac ordered. Started iron supplementation. Patient last colonoscopy was 12 years ago (age 59) - overdue for screening. Will schedule if stool guaiac positive.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up on weight loss and anemia, now having some belly discomfort
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Patient with continued weight loss - now down to 178 lbs (12 lbs total over 4 months). Hemoglobin declining despite iron supplementation (12.8 to 12.2). Ferritin minimally improved. Stool guaiac was negative. Now reports vague intermittent lower abdominal cramping and notes stools sometimes harder to pass. B12 and folate normal. Referred for upper endoscopy to evaluate for gastric source of bleeding/malabsorption. Patient hesitant about colonoscopy, wants to 'see what EGD shows first.'

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: EGD results follow-up, weight still dropping, constipation worse
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: EGD results: mild gastritis, no ulcers, biopsies benign. This does NOT explain progressive weight loss and anemia. Patient now down 18 lbs total (190 to 172 lbs over 5 months). Hemoglobin continues to decline (11.4). Ferritin not improving despite iron therapy. New complaints of worsening constipation and crampy abdominal pain. CRP and ESR elevated suggesting inflammation. NEED COLONOSCOPY - this could be colon cancer, IBD, or other colonic pathology. Strongly recommended colonoscopy. Patient agrees but wants to wait until after daughter's wedding in 6 weeks.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Weight loss continues, very fatigued, noticed blood on toilet paper few times
procedures_ordered: Colonoscopy URGENT - called GI to expedite
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ALARMING PROGRESSION. Patient now 22 lbs below baseline weight (190 to 168 lbs over 6 months). Hemoglobin 10.2 - moderate anemia worsening despite iron. Now reports visible blood on toilet paper with bowel movements. Severe fatigue limiting activities. Platelets elevated at 445 (reactive thrombocytosis - concerning for malignancy). CRP and ESR markedly elevated. This is RED FLAG constellation: age >70 + progressive weight loss + worsening anemia + GI bleeding + inflammatory markers. HIGH SUSPICION FOR COLORECTAL CANCER. Called GI to expedite colonoscopy - scheduled for next week. Ordered CEA tumor marker.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Colonoscopy results discussion

new_acute: Adenocarcinoma of sigmoid colon, Stage II (C18.7)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: COLONOSCOPY RESULTS: Large, partially obstructing mass in sigmoid colon (5cm). Biopsies confirm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. CEA elevated at 42 ng/mL (normal <5). This explains entire clinical picture - progressive weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, bowel changes, bleeding, inflammatory markers. CT staging pending but no obvious metastases on initial imaging. Likely Stage II or III. Referred urgently to surgical oncology for resection. Patient and family devastated but also relieved to have diagnosis. In retrospect, colonoscopy should have been done 4-5 months ago when red flags first appeared. Delay may have allowed progression. Important lesson about acting quickly on alarm symptoms.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the constellation of alarm symptoms (weight loss + anemia + age >70) early in the timeline
Understanding that negative stool guaiac does NOT rule out GI malignancy
Identifying the pattern of progressive anemia despite iron supplementation as highly concerning
Recognizing reactive thrombocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers as potential cancer signals
Understanding the critical delay in performing colonoscopy despite multiple red flags
Connecting seemingly disparate symptoms (weight loss, anemia, constipation, fatigue) to a unifying diagnosis
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize occult cancer presentation through progressive symptoms over time, (2) identify alarm symptoms requiring urgent investigation, (3) understand that normal or minimally helpful initial tests do not exclude serious pathology, (4) track multiple converging clinical indicators (weight loss, anemia, bleeding, inflammatory markers), (5) recognize critical diagnostic delays as care gaps, and (6) appreciate the urgency needed when multiple red flags are present. The LLM should flag concern by V1-V2 with weight loss and anemia in elderly patient, recognize high suspicion for malignancy by V3 with progressive symptoms and normal EGD, identify critical urgency by V4 with overt bleeding and severe anemia, and understand that the 4-5 month delay to colonoscopy was a significant care gap that may have affected outcomes.

allergies.reaction: Rash, unknown details (patient report from childhood)

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive BP elevation from 112/68 at baseline to 168/108, indicating preeclampsia development
Rising proteinuria (negative to 4+ protein) correlating with BP elevation and symptoms
Declining platelet count and elevated liver enzymes indicating HELLP syndrome development
Warning symptoms (severe headache, RUQ pain, visual changes) preceding severe preeclampsia with features

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: First prenatal visit, about 10 weeks pregnant
procedures_ordered: Dating ultrasound - single viable IUP, 10w3d, EDD November 22, 2024
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: First prenatal visit. G1P0 (primigravida). 28 yo African American female. Risk factors for preeclampsia: African American race, primigravida, family history (mother had preeclampsia). Pre-pregnancy weight 142 lbs, current 145 lbs. BMI 24.1 - normal. Baseline BP 112/68. No proteinuria. Patient healthy, no chronic conditions. Discussed warning signs of preeclampsia given risk factors. Standard prenatal care plan.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Routine visit, 20 weeks, anatomy scan completed
procedures_ordered: Anatomy ultrasound - normal male fetus, all structures normal
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 20 week visit. Weight 155 lbs (10 lb gain, appropriate). BP 118/74 (stable). Anatomy scan normal. Fundal height appropriate. Fetal movement felt. No complaints. Hemoglobin 11.8 - borderline, monitoring. Continue routine prenatal care.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 28 week visit, noticed some swelling in hands and feet past week
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 28 weeks. Weight 168 lbs (23 lb gain, upper limit of normal). BP 138/86 - ELEVATED from baseline 112/68. 1+ pitting edema bilateral hands and feet. Patient reports rings tight. Trace proteinuria on dipstick. Concerning for early preeclampsia. Ordered 24-hour urine protein. Uric acid 5.2 (borderline). Labs otherwise normal including platelets 228, liver enzymes normal. Patient to monitor BP at home twice daily. Return in 1 week for recheck. Instructed on warning signs: severe headache, vision changes, RUQ pain, decreased fetal movement. If 24-hr protein >300mg, diagnosis of preeclampsia confirmed.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up visit, 31 weeks, having headaches past few days
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PREECLAMPSIA DIAGNOSED. 24-hr urine protein 450mg (>300 confirms diagnosis). BP 152/96. 2+ proteinuria. 2+ edema now to knees. Patient reports frontal headaches daily x3 days, responding to Tylenol. No visual changes, no RUQ pain. Platelets declining to 185 (from 228 three weeks ago). Liver enzymes mildly elevated: ALT 42, AST 48. Uric acid 6.8. This is preeclampsia without severe features currently, but trending worse. NST reactive. Fetus appropriate size. Plan: twice weekly NSTs and labs starting now. Steroids for fetal lung maturity given. Goal to reach 37 weeks if stable, but deliver earlier if severe features develop. Patient on modified bed rest. Home BP monitoring.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe headache that won't go away, seeing spots, pain under right ribs

started: Magnesium sulfate IV for seizure prophylaxis
Betamethasone IM for fetal lung maturity (completed)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: SEVERE PREECLAMPSIA WITH HELLP SYNDROME - OBSTETRIC EMERGENCY. Patient presenting at 32w1d with severe unrelenting headache, visual disturbances (scotomas), and severe RUQ/epigastric pain. BP 168/108. HELLP SYNDROME CRITERIA MET: Hemolysis (Hgb 9.8 down from 10.8, LDH 685, schistocytes on smear), Elevated Liver enzymes (AST 242, ALT 168), Low Platelets (98, down from 185). 4+ proteinuria. Creatinine rising to 1.2. This represents severe preeclampsia with severe features. Started magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Labetalol IV for BP control. Steroids completed. IMMEDIATE DELIVERY INDICATED despite 32 weeks gestation - maternal life-threatening condition. Cesarean section performed - delivered 32w1d male infant, 3 lbs 14 oz, Apgars 7/8, admitted to NICU. Patient to ICU for monitoring. This case demonstrates rapid progression from preeclampsia to HELLP syndrome over 1 week.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Postpartum visit, 6 weeks after emergency delivery
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 6 week postpartum visit. Patient recovered well from severe preeclampsia/HELLP. Spent 4 days in ICU post-delivery, platelets and liver enzymes normalized by post-op day 3. Discharged on post-op day 5. BP normalized immediately after delivery. Current BP 132/82 - borderline but acceptable. No proteinuria. Labs normalized - platelets 242, liver enzymes normal, hemoglobin recovered. Weight 152 lbs (7 lbs above pre-pregnancy). Incision healed well. Baby in NICU for 3 weeks, now home and doing well. IMPORTANT COUNSELING: Patient at HIGH RISK for preeclampsia in future pregnancies (25-50% recurrence risk). Also at increased risk for chronic hypertension and cardiovascular disease later in life. Discussed low-dose aspirin for future pregnancies starting at 12 weeks. Recommended close preconception counseling before next pregnancy. Patient choosing long-acting reversible contraception (IUD) given risks.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the progression from normal BP to preeclampsia to severe preeclampsia with HELLP
Understanding the significance of rising BP in conjunction with proteinuria
Identifying warning symptoms (headache, visual changes, RUQ pain) as severe features
Recognizing HELLP syndrome criteria (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)
Understanding the rapidity of progression requiring emergency delivery despite prematurity
Appreciating long-term cardiovascular risk after preeclampsia/HELLP
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) track progressive BP elevation across pregnancy, (2) recognize preeclampsia development through BP + proteinuria, (3) identify laboratory trends indicating worsening disease (declining platelets, rising liver enzymes), (4) connect warning symptoms with severe features requiring immediate intervention, (5) understand HELLP syndrome as life-threatening complication, (6) recognize the need for emergency delivery despite prematurity, and (7) appreciate long-term health implications. The LLM should flag concern at V3 with elevated BP and edema, recognize preeclampsia diagnosis at V4, identify rapid progression and severe features at V5 requiring emergency intervention, and understand at V6 the implications for future pregnancy and cardiovascular health. This case demonstrates how quickly preeclampsia can progress from mild to life-threatening.

allergies.reaction: Hives, mild bronchospasm during prior CT scan
Severe rash, discontinued after prior stent

ground_truth_correlations.description: Acute chest pain with ST-segment elevation and troponin rise indicating STEMI
Progressive troponin elevation from 0.05 to peak 45.2 ng/mL indicating large MI with myocardial necrosis
Post-MI heart failure development with declining EF and rising BNP
Delayed presentation (12 hours from symptom onset) resulting in larger infarct and worse outcomes

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe crushing chest pain since yesterday evening, pain radiating to left arm and jaw
procedures_ordered: EKG - ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF (inferior STEMI)
Chest X-ray - clear lung fields, normal cardiac silhouette
STAT cardiology consult for cardiac catheterization
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ACUTE STEMI - EMERGENCY. 58 yo male presenting with 12 hours of severe substernal chest pain, radiating to left arm and jaw, associated with diaphoresis, nausea. Pain started at 8pm yesterday while watching TV. Patient delayed seeking care, hoping it would resolve. EKG shows classic inferior STEMI with ST elevation in II, III, aVF. Troponin significantly elevated at 8.5. DELAYED PRESENTATION - symptom onset 12 hours ago. Activated cardiac cath lab. Given aspirin, heparin, beta-blocker, morphine. Patient to cath lab emergently. Risk factors: diabetes, hyperlipidemia, obesity, hypertension, family history (father MI at age 52). Pre-treated with IV fluids and antihistamine due to contrast allergy history.

social_history_updates.smoking: current (1 pack per day x 35 years)

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-catheterization day 1, CCU admission

started: Ticagrelor 90mg twice daily (alternative to clopidogrel due to allergy)

new_acute: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, inferior wall, acute (I21.19)
Right coronary artery occlusion, status post PCI with stent (I25.10)

procedures_ordered: Cardiac catheterization report: 100% occlusion of RCA, successful PCI with drug-eluting stent placement
Echocardiogram: EF 35%, inferior wall akinesis, mild mitral regurgitation
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Post-cath day 1. Successful PCI to RCA with single drug-eluting stent for 100% occlusion. TIMI 3 flow achieved. However, LARGE MI - troponin peaked at 45.2 (very high), CK 2850. Delayed presentation (12 hours) resulted in significant myocardial necrosis before reperfusion. Echo shows EF 35% with inferior wall akinesis. Now has systolic heart failure. Started GDMT: aspirin, ticagrelor (can't use clopidogrel due to allergy history), beta-blocker, ACE-I, high-dose statin. Creatinine slightly elevated at 1.4 (contrast-induced nephropathy vs cardiorenal). Patient hemodynamically stable, chest pain resolved. Will monitor for complications - arrhythmias, heart failure, free wall rupture. Cardiac rehab referral. Smoking cessation critical.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital day 5, transfer to step-down unit, some shortness of breath

new_acute: Coronary artery disease with stent (I25.10, Z95.5)

procedures_ordered: Chest X-ray: mild pulmonary vascular congestion
Repeat echo: EF 32% (slightly worse), inferior/inferolateral akinesis
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Hospital day 5. Patient developing post-MI heart failure symptoms - mild dyspnea on exertion, 5 lb weight gain, mild crackles at bases. BNP elevated at 1250. Repeat echo shows EF declined to 32%. Started diuretic therapy with furosemide and spironolactone. Uptitrated ACE-I. Patient hemodynamically stable. No arrhythmias on telemetry. CK trending down (was 2850, now 485). Discharge planning - will go home in 1-2 days. Extensive education on dual antiplatelet therapy (must take aspirin AND ticagrelor for minimum 1 year - cannot stop), heart failure medications, lifestyle modifications. Smoking cessation critical - provided resources. Cardiac rehab enrolled.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-MI follow-up, 4 weeks after discharge, feeling weak and tired

active_chronic: Coronary artery disease with history of MI and stent (I25.10, Z95.5)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 4 week post-MI follow-up. Patient doing reasonably well. Enrolled in cardiac rehab, attending 3x per week. 7 lb weight loss (intentional diet modification). Reports fatigue and weakness - likely deconditioning from MI and beta-blocker effect. No chest pain, no dyspnea at rest. Some dyspnea with exertion but improving. Echo shows EF improved to 38%. BNP down to 680. LDL excellent at 68 on high-dose statin. A1c 7.8 - needs better diabetes control. CRITICAL: Patient MUST continue dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + ticagrelor) for minimum 1 year - reinforced multiple times. Patient quit smoking 2 weeks ago - using nicotine patches. Excellent progress. Continue all medications. Gradual return to activities as tolerated through cardiac rehab.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 6-month post-MI follow-up, doing well overall

active_chronic: Coronary artery disease with history of MI and stent (I25.10, Z95.5)

procedures_ordered: Stress test at 1 year if no symptoms
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Excellent 6-month post-MI progress. Patient lost 20 lbs total (215 to 195), completed cardiac rehab, remains smoke-free (6 months!), exercising regularly. EF improved to 42%. BNP near normal at 385. Diabetes control improved (A1c 6.8). LDL at goal (<70). No angina, no heart failure symptoms. Functionally independent, back to work. Will continue dual antiplatelet therapy for full year, then transition to aspirin monotherapy after discussion with cardiology. Patient understands importance of lifelong risk factor modification - diet, exercise, smoking cessation, medication adherence. This case demonstrates: (1) Consequences of delayed presentation in STEMI, (2) Development of post-MI heart failure, (3) Importance of comprehensive cardiac rehab and lifestyle modification, (4) Recovery potential with optimal medical therapy.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the significance of delayed presentation (12 hours) on infarct size
Understanding the relationship between troponin elevation magnitude and myocardial damage
Connecting acute MI with development of post-MI heart failure (EF decline)
Recognizing the importance of dual antiplatelet therapy after stent placement
Understanding contrast allergy management in emergency cardiac catheterization
Tracking recovery trajectory through serial EF measurements
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize acute STEMI presentation and need for emergency intervention, (2) understand impact of time-to-treatment on outcomes, (3) track troponin kinetics and correlation with infarct size, (4) recognize post-MI complications (heart failure development), (5) understand importance of secondary prevention medications, (6) appreciate role of lifestyle modifications and cardiac rehabilitation in recovery, and (7) recognize allergy considerations affecting treatment choices (clopidogrel allergy requiring ticagrelor, contrast allergy requiring premedication). The LLM should identify the critical nature of delayed presentation at V1, recognize massive MI with high troponin at V2, identify post-MI heart failure at V3, and track positive recovery trajectory through V4-V5 with lifestyle modifications.

ground_truth_correlations.description: New onset atrial fibrillation with palpitations and irregular heart rhythm
Progressive decline in heart rate control despite medication escalation
Delayed anticoagulation initiation despite high stroke risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score 5)
Transient ischemic attack (TIA) occurring while on inadequate anticoagulation

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Heart racing and fluttering sensation in chest for past week
procedures_ordered: EKG - sinus rhythm, rate 118, no acute changes
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 68 yo female with 1 week of palpitations and racing heart. Heart rate 118 in office. EKG today shows sinus tachycardia. Pulse irregular on exam. No chest pain, no dyspnea. Patient anxious about symptoms. Started low-dose beta-blocker. Ordered Holter monitor to capture rhythm during symptoms. TSH to rule out hyperthyroidism. RTC in 2 weeks for Holter results.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up for Holter monitor results, still having episodes of rapid heartbeat

dose_changed: Metoprolol tartrate increased to 50mg twice daily

procedures_ordered: Holter monitor results: Multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation, longest 4 hours, heart rates 110-145 during AFib
EKG today - atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, rate 96
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ATRIAL FIBRILLATION diagnosed on Holter monitor. Multiple paroxysmal AFib episodes over 24 hours. EKG today also shows AFib. TSH normal. Patient has multiple stroke risk factors: age 68, female, hypertension. CHA2DS2-VASc score = 4 (age, female, hypertension) - HIGH RISK for stroke, anticoagulation indicated. However, patient very anxious about 'blood thinners' after reading online. Spent significant time discussing stroke risk (annual risk ~4% without anticoagulation). Patient wants to 'think about it' before starting anticoagulation. Increased beta-blocker for rate control. Ordered echo to assess heart structure. Cardiology referral for AFib management and discussion of anticoagulation vs cardioversion options. CRITICAL: Patient needs anticoagulation but declining currently.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Cardiology follow-up completed, still having palpitations, agreed to start blood thinner
procedures_ordered: Echocardiogram results: Normal LV function, EF 60%, mild LA enlargement, no valvular disease
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Saw cardiology. Echo shows preserved EF 60%, mild LA enlargement. Cardiologist discussed rate vs rhythm control, anticoagulation options. Patient finally agreed to anticoagulation after cardiologist reinforced stroke risk. Started warfarin (patient preferred over DOACs due to cost/insurance coverage). Explained INR monitoring, dietary vitamin K considerations, drug interactions. Patient understanding seems good. Will need frequent INR checks initially. CHA2DS2-VASc score actually 5 (rereviewed - age, female, hypertension, vascular disease history - patient had DVT 10 years ago, forgot to mention initially). VERY HIGH stroke risk. Critical that INR maintained in therapeutic range 2-3.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Sudden onset of slurred speech and right arm weakness this morning, resolved after 20 minutes
procedures_ordered: CT head - no acute hemorrhage or infarct
MRI brain - small acute infarct in left MCA territory
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK / SMALL STROKE. Patient presented with sudden slurred speech and right arm weakness at 9am, resolved by 9:20am. By ED arrival at 10am, neurologically intact. CT negative for hemorrhage. MRI shows small acute infarct in left MCA territory consistent with cardioembolic stroke from atrial fibrillation. CRITICAL FINDING: INR only 1.4, SUBTHERAPEUTIC (should be 2-3). Patient on warfarin only 5 weeks. Reviewed INR records - has been erratic: 1.2, 2.8, 1.6, 1.4. Patient admits inconsistent warfarin dosing - sometimes forgets, sometimes takes double dose when remembers she forgot. Also eating large amounts of leafy greens inconsistently. This stroke was PREVENTABLE with adequate anticoagulation. Started high-dose statin. Admitted for observation, telemetry monitoring. Neurology recommends switching to DOAC (direct oral anticoagulant) - more predictable, no monitoring needed, better for non-adherent patients. Discussed with patient - will transition to apixaban.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up after TIA, now on apixaban, feeling well
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 1 month post-TIA. Patient doing well, no neurologic deficits. No recurrent symptoms. Switched from warfarin to apixaban - much easier for patient (no INR monitoring, no dietary restrictions, twice daily dosing). Patient reports excellent adherence with apixaban - using pill organizer and phone alarms. Heart rate better controlled on metoprolol. Still in paroxysmal AFib. LDL excellent at 78 on high-dose statin. BP improved. Patient very motivated after stroke scare. This case demonstrates: (1) Importance of CHA2DS2-VASc scoring and early anticoagulation, (2) Consequences of subtherapeutic anticoagulation, (3) Impact of medication non-adherence on stroke risk, (4) Advantages of DOACs over warfarin for certain patients, (5) Stroke as preventable complication of untreated/undertreated AFib. Patient's stroke was PREVENTABLE - either earlier anticoagulation or better warfarin adherence would have prevented this.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing delayed anticoagulation as a critical care gap despite high stroke risk
Understanding CHA2DS2-VASc scoring and its implications for anticoagulation decisions
Connecting subtherapeutic INR with TIA/stroke occurrence
Identifying medication non-adherence as contributing factor to adverse outcome
Understanding the difference between rate control and anticoagulation in AFib
Recognizing preventable nature of the stroke with earlier/better anticoagulation
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize new-onset atrial fibrillation and its clinical significance, (2) calculate stroke risk using CHA2DS2-VASc score, (3) identify delayed anticoagulation as a care gap despite clear indications, (4) understand the relationship between subtherapeutic anticoagulation and stroke risk, (5) recognize medication non-adherence and its consequences, (6) understand advantages of DOACs over warfarin for certain patient populations, and (7) identify the preventable nature of complications when guideline-directed therapy is not followed. The LLM should flag high stroke risk at V2 when AFib is diagnosed, identify the care gap of delayed anticoagulation at V2-V3, recognize subtherapeutic INR as critical finding at V4, connect poor adherence with stroke occurrence, and understand the improved safety/adherence profile with DOAC switch at V5. This case emphasizes that strokes from AFib are largely preventable with appropriate anticoagulation.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Recurrent sinus infections (5 episodes in 8 months) despite multiple antibiotic courses indicating chronic sinusitis
Nasal polyps and chronic inflammation on CT correlating with persistent symptoms and allergic history
Failure of medical management (antibiotics, steroids, nasal sprays) requiring surgical intervention
Delayed ENT referral despite recurrent infections and inadequate response to medical therapy

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Sinus infection, facial pain and pressure, thick yellow nasal discharge x1 week

continued: Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily (for allergies)
started: Azithromycin 500mg day 1, then 250mg daily x4 days (Z-pack)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 42 yo female with 1 week of facial pain, pressure over maxillary sinuses, thick purulent nasal discharge, post-nasal drip, mild headache. Low-grade fever 99.8. Exam: tenderness over maxillary and frontal sinuses, purulent discharge in nares, pharynx mildly erythematous from post-nasal drip. Diagnosed acute bacterial sinusitis. Started azithromycin (penicillin allergy documented). Patient has history of seasonal allergies, already on fluticasone nasal spray. This is her third sinus infection in past 6 months per patient report.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Another sinus infection, same symptoms as before, not getting better with antibiotics

continued: Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Fourth sinus infection in 6 months. Patient completed azithromycin in February with initial improvement, but symptoms returned within 3 weeks. Presents now with fever 100.2, severe facial pain, thick green nasal discharge. Exam: significant tenderness over all sinuses, purulent drainage, nasal mucosa edematous and inflamed. This is becoming recurrent/chronic pattern. Started fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin) for broader coverage and oral steroids for inflammation. Discussed possibility of chronic sinusitis. Should consider ENT referral if this doesn't resolve or recurs again.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Sinus symptoms never really went away, now worse again, can't breathe through nose, constant pressure

continued: Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: CHRONIC SINUSITIS - fifth episode in 8 months. Patient reports symptoms never fully resolved after last infection. Now with complete nasal obstruction, can't breathe through nose, constant facial pressure, thick post-nasal drip, reduced sense of smell. No fever today. Exam: nasal passages almost completely obstructed with boggy, inflamed mucosa bilaterally. Visualized what appears to be polyps in left naris. Sinuses very tender. This is CHRONIC RHINOSINUSITIS. Started augmentin (amoxicillin-clavulanate works for penicillin allergy when true allergy is just rash/hives, not anaphylaxis), oral steroids, added montelukast for anti-inflammatory effect and allergic component. Ordered CT sinuses. ENT REFERRAL - patient needs specialist evaluation, likely needs functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) if medical management continues to fail.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: ENT follow-up completed, discussing CT results and surgery options

continued: Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily
started: Budesonide nasal rinse (0.5mg in 240mL saline) twice daily

procedures_ordered: CT sinuses results: Complete opacification of maxillary sinuses bilaterally, near-complete opacification of ethmoid and frontal sinuses, nasal polyps throughout nasal cavity and ethmoid sinuses, deviated nasal septum to right, ostiomeatal complex obstruction bilaterally
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Saw ENT specialist. CT shows severe chronic pansinusitis with extensive nasal polyposis - explains recurrent infections and treatment failures. ENT recommends functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) with polypectomy and septoplasty. Patient scheduled for surgery in 4 weeks. In meantime, started on budesonide sinus rinses (steroid irrigation) to reduce inflammation. Will also see allergist for comprehensive testing and potential immunotherapy - environmental allergies are contributing factor to polyp formation. ENT explained surgery will open blocked sinuses, remove polyps, improve drainage. Patient understanding and agreeable to surgical plan. This case shows progression from recurrent acute sinusitis to chronic sinusitis with polyposis requiring surgical intervention when medical management fails.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-op follow-up, 6 weeks after sinus surgery, doing much better

continued: Fluticasone nasal spray 2 sprays each nostril daily

active_chronic: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, status post FESS (J33.1, Z98.89)

procedures_ordered: Allergy testing results: Strongly positive to dust mites, mold, ragweed, tree pollen
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 6 weeks post-FESS with polypectomy and septoplasty. Surgery successful per ENT - all polyps removed, sinuses opened, septum corrected. Patient reports DRAMATIC improvement - can breathe through nose for first time in years, no facial pressure, sense of smell returning. No infections since surgery. Continuing nasal steroid spray and budesonide rinses to prevent polyp recurrence. Allergy testing showed multiple strong environmental allergies. Starting sublingual immunotherapy (allergy drops) - proven to reduce polyp recurrence and improve long-term control. Patient very satisfied with surgical outcome. Will need ongoing ENT surveillance for polyp recurrence. This case demonstrates: (1) Natural history of chronic sinusitis with polyposis, (2) Failure of medical management alone in severe disease, (3) Role of surgery in refractory cases, (4) Importance of addressing underlying allergies to prevent recurrence, (5) Need for long-term maintenance therapy post-surgery.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing the pattern of recurrent acute sinusitis progressing to chronic sinusitis
Understanding when medical management has failed and surgical referral is indicated
Identifying nasal polyps as a complication of chronic inflammation and allergies
Recognizing the role of environmental allergies in chronic sinusitis pathophysiology
Understanding the importance of post-surgical maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence
Identifying the care gap of delayed ENT referral despite multiple treatment failures
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize recurrent sinusitis pattern (5 episodes in 8 months) indicating chronic disease, (2) identify treatment failure with multiple antibiotic courses, (3) understand the progression from acute recurrent to chronic sinusitis with complications, (4) recognize nasal polyps on exam and imaging as structural cause of symptoms, (5) understand when surgical intervention is indicated after medical management failure, (6) appreciate the role of allergies in chronic sinusitis, (7) identify delayed specialist referral as a care gap, and (8) understand importance of post-surgical maintenance and immunotherapy. The LLM should flag recurrent pattern by V2, recognize inadequate response to medical therapy by V3, identify need for imaging and ENT referral, understand CT findings showing severe disease at V4, and appreciate successful surgical outcome and prevention strategies at V5. This case emphasizes that chronic sinusitis often requires multimodal treatment including surgery and allergy management, not just antibiotics.

allergies.reaction: Severe rash, Stevens-Johnson syndrome risk per patient

ground_truth_correlations.description: Sudden unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus and vertigo indicating inner ear pathology (SSHL)
Critical delay in treatment - patient waited 5 days before seeking care, missing optimal treatment window
Incomplete hearing recovery despite high-dose steroids due to delayed treatment initiation
Permanent hearing loss and persistent tinnitus resulting in significant functional impairment

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Can't hear out of left ear for past 5 days, ringing in ear, some dizziness
procedures_ordered: Otoscopic exam - bilateral TMs clear, no effusion, no cerumen impaction
Weber test - lateralizes to RIGHT ear (away from affected left ear)
Rinne test - LEFT ear: bone conduction > air conduction (abnormal); RIGHT ear: air > bone (normal)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 55 yo male with SUDDEN onset left-sided hearing loss 5 days ago. Woke up on May 18th and noticed couldn't hear out of left ear. Associated with loud ringing (tinnitus) and episodes of dizziness/vertigo. NO ear pain, no discharge, no recent URI, no trauma. Exam: TMs normal bilaterally, no obvious cause. Weber lateralizes to RIGHT (good ear) - suggests sensorineural loss on left. Rinne shows bone > air on left (abnormal). This is CONCERNING for sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSHL) - ENT EMERGENCY requiring urgent treatment. CRITICAL: Patient waited 5 days before coming in - optimal treatment window is within 72 hours of onset. Placed STAT ENT referral. Patient has diabetes and hypertension - risk factors for vascular causes of SSHL.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: ENT urgent appointment, sudden hearing loss evaluation

started: Prednisone 60mg daily x7 days, then taper over 2 weeks
Meclizine 25mg three times daily as needed for vertigo

new_acute: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss, left ear (H91.21)

procedures_ordered: Audiogram: LEFT ear - severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss across all frequencies (70-90 dB loss); RIGHT ear - normal hearing
Tympanometry - normal bilaterally (middle ear function intact)
MRI brain/IAC with contrast ordered to rule out acoustic neuroma
Labs: CBC, CMP, ESR, ANA, RPR - to rule out autoimmune, infectious, or vascular causes
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ENT EVALUATION: Confirmed SUDDEN SENSORINEURAL HEARING LOSS (SSHL) - idiopathic. Audiogram shows severe-to-profound hearing loss in left ear (70-90 dB across all frequencies). RIGHT ear normal. This is a TRUE ENT EMERGENCY. Unfortunately, patient delayed seeking care for 5 DAYS - optimal treatment window is <72 hours from onset. Prognosis for recovery is significantly worse with delayed treatment. Started high-dose oral prednisone immediately - may help reduce inflammation in inner ear. Will also consider intratympanic steroid injections if no improvement in 1 week. Ordered MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology (acoustic neuroma, though typically causes gradual hearing loss). Most cases of SSHL are idiopathic (unknown cause). Patient has vascular risk factors (diabetes, hypertension) which may contribute. Educated patient that recovery is uncertain given delay in presentation.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 2 week follow-up, completed steroid course, minimal improvement in hearing

active_chronic: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss, left ear (H91.21)

procedures_ordered: Repeat audiogram: LEFT ear - severe sensorineural hearing loss, minimal improvement (65-85 dB loss, improved 5-10 dB from baseline); RIGHT ear - remains normal
MRI brain/IAC - negative for acoustic neuroma, no structural abnormalities
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 2 weeks post-treatment initiation. Completed oral steroid course. Repeat audiogram shows MINIMAL improvement - only 5-10 dB recovery. Still has severe hearing loss in left ear. MRI negative for tumor or structural cause. Vertigo has resolved. Tinnitus persists - very bothersome to patient. Started intratympanic steroid injections (dexamethasone injected directly through eardrum into middle ear space) - can deliver higher steroid concentration to inner ear. Will do series of 3 injections over 2 weeks. However, prognosis is guarded - delayed treatment (5 days from onset) significantly reduces likelihood of recovery. Most recovery occurs in first 2-4 weeks; if no improvement by 6-8 weeks, hearing loss is likely permanent. Patient very distressed - hearing loss affecting work (he's a high school teacher, can't hear students on left side), social situations difficult. Side effects from steroids: BP elevated to 152/92 (was 138/84), glucose elevated to 168 (was 118), weight gain 4 lbs.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 8 week follow-up, completed all treatments, some improvement but still significant hearing loss

active_chronic: Sensorineural hearing loss, left ear, permanent (H90.42)

procedures_ordered: Final audiogram: LEFT ear - moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss (50-70 dB loss across frequencies); RIGHT ear - normal
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 8 weeks from onset. Completed all treatments: oral prednisone and intratympanic steroid injections (3 sessions). Final audiogram shows PARTIAL recovery - improved from 70-90 dB loss to 50-70 dB loss. This represents moderate-to-severe hearing loss. Patient regained some hearing (about 20-30 dB improvement overall) but has PERMANENT significant hearing loss. Vertigo completely resolved. Tinnitus persists - constant ringing/buzzing in left ear, very distressing to patient. Discussed prognosis: unlikely to see further spontaneous improvement at this point. Referred to audiology for hearing aid - will need amplification. Also enrolled in tinnitus management program (sound therapy, cognitive behavioral techniques). Patient disappointed with outcome - understandably frustrated that delay in seeking care may have affected recovery. Reviewed that SSHL is a medical emergency requiring treatment within 72 hours for best outcomes. Even with prompt treatment, only 50-60% of patients achieve good recovery; delayed treatment significantly worsens prognosis. This case will result in permanent disability.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up with hearing aid, adjusting to new reality of hearing loss

active_chronic: Sensorineural hearing loss, left ear, permanent (H90.42)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 5 months from initial presentation. Patient fitted with hearing aid in left ear - reports significant improvement in ability to function. Hearing aid helps amplify sounds but doesn't restore normal hearing. Still struggles in noisy environments, group conversations. Tinnitus remains constant but patient learning coping strategies through tinnitus management program - using white noise at night, CBT techniques. Patient reports some depression and social isolation related to hearing loss - may benefit from counseling. Lost 5 lbs through diet/exercise. BP and glucose better controlled. This case demonstrates: (1) SSHL is a true ENT emergency requiring immediate treatment, (2) Delayed presentation (>72 hours) significantly worsens prognosis, (3) Even with aggressive treatment, recovery may be incomplete, (4) Permanent hearing loss has significant functional and psychological impact, (5) Importance of patient education about red flag symptoms requiring urgent care, (6) Role of rehabilitation (hearing aids, tinnitus management) when recovery incomplete. Patient's outcome could have been better with immediate presentation - critical teaching point.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing sudden sensorineural hearing loss as a medical emergency requiring urgent treatment
Understanding the critical importance of time-to-treatment (<72 hours) on prognosis
Identifying the 5-day delay as a major factor in poor outcome
Correlating delayed treatment with incomplete hearing recovery
Understanding the difference between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss
Recognizing permanent functional impairment despite maximal medical therapy
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSHL) as an ENT emergency requiring immediate intervention, (2) understand the critical time-window for treatment (optimal <72 hours), (3) identify patient delay in seeking care as a major factor affecting outcome, (4) track partial hearing recovery through serial audiograms, (5) understand that even with aggressive treatment (oral and intratympanic steroids), delayed presentation results in worse outcomes, (6) recognize permanent disability and need for rehabilitation, and (7) appreciate psychological and functional impacts of sudden hearing loss. The LLM should flag the 5-day delay at V1 as critical, recognize SSHL diagnosis and urgent treatment initiation at V2, identify minimal improvement despite treatment at V3, understand permanent hearing loss by V4, and appreciate long-term disability and rehabilitation needs at V5. This case emphasizes that SSHL is a 'stroke of the ear' requiring emergency treatment, and patient education about urgent symptoms is crucial.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Progressive worsening from pharyngitis to peritonsillar abscess with airway compromise
Progressive leukocytosis and inflammatory markers indicating worsening bacterial infection
Failure of oral antibiotics for pharyngitis leading to abscess formation requiring surgical drainage
Patient delay in follow-up despite worsening symptoms and inadequate initial antibiotic coverage

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe sore throat x3 days, fever, hard to swallow

started: Amoxicillin 500mg three times daily x10 days
Ibuprofen 600mg every 6 hours as needed for pain/fever
Acetaminophen 650mg every 6 hours alternating with ibuprofen

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 28 yo male with 3 days severe sore throat, fever to 101.8, odynophagia (painful swallowing). Denies cough, congestion. Exam: pharynx markedly erythematous, tonsils 3+ enlarged with white exudate bilaterally, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Rapid strep negative but sent culture. WBC 13.5 (elevated). Started amoxicillin empirically for bacterial pharyngitis/tonsillitis. Advised fluids, rest, pain control. Return if worse or not improving in 48-72 hours.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Sore throat much worse, can barely swallow or open mouth, voice sounds different, drooling

continued: Amoxicillin 500mg three times daily (patient reports taking as prescribed)

procedures_ordered: CT neck with contrast - LEFT peritonsillar abscess 3.2cm x 2.8cm with mass effect displacing airway medially
Throat culture from 7/8 resulted: Group A Streptococcus positive (came back after patient already started amoxicillin)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: PERITONSILLAR ABSCESS - ENT EMERGENCY. Patient took amoxicillin as prescribed but symptoms WORSENED dramatically. Now with high fever 103.2, severe dysphagia (can't swallow even saliva - drooling), trismus (can barely open mouth), 'hot potato' muffled voice, deviation of uvula to RIGHT side. Exam very limited due to trismus but visible bulging of left soft palate with uvular deviation. WBC 18.5 (was 13.5 six days ago). CRP markedly elevated 125.6. CT confirms LARGE left peritonsillar abscess 3.2cm with airway displacement. This is AIRWAY EMERGENCY - abscess could rupture and cause aspiration or cause complete airway obstruction. Started IV steroids, IV fluids (patient hasn't eaten/drunk in 2 days due to pain), morphine for pain. STAT ENT consult for incision and drainage. Patient admitted. Retrospective review: throat culture from initial visit came back positive for Group A Strep - amoxicillin SHOULD have been effective, but patient progressed to abscess despite treatment. Suggests either resistant organism, inadequate drug penetration, or abscess was already forming at initial presentation.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital day 2, status post I&D of peritonsillar abscess

continued: Morphine IV as needed for pain (using less)

new_acute: Peritonsillar abscess, left, status post I&D (J36)

procedures_ordered: I&D performed by ENT in OR under general anesthesia - drained 15mL purulent material
Abscess culture: Group A Streptococcus and Fusobacterium necrophorum (anaerobe)
Blood cultures x2 - positive for Group A Streptococcus (BACTEREMIA)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Post-op day 1 from I&D of peritonsillar abscess. ENT drained 15mL of purulent material in OR. Pathology CRITICAL: abscess grew Group A Strep (as expected from throat culture) PLUS Fusobacterium necrophorum (anaerobic bacteria). This polymicrobial infection explains why amoxicillin alone was insufficient - amoxicillin doesn't cover anaerobes well. Blood cultures POSITIVE for Group A Strep - patient had BACTEREMIA (bacteria in bloodstream), which is serious complication. Now on IV clindamycin (covers both strep and anaerobes) and ampicillin-sulbactam for broad coverage. Patient significantly improved after drainage - fever down to 99.8, WBC improving (18.5 to 12.2), CRP trending down, able to swallow liquids and soft foods, trismus resolved, pain much better. Will continue IV antibiotics x48 hours then transition to oral if continued improvement. Minimum 2 week total antibiotic course. ENT recommends elective tonsillectomy in 6-8 weeks to prevent recurrence (30% recurrence rate of peritonsillar abscess without tonsillectomy).

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Hospital discharge, feeling much better, able to eat soft foods

started: Clindamycin 450mg by mouth four times daily x10 more days (total 14 days)
Hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5-325mg every 6 hours as needed for pain (avoiding codeine due to allergy)

clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Discharged after 4 days hospitalization. Completed 72 hours IV antibiotics with excellent response. WBC normalized to 9.2, CRP down to 24.5 (was 125.6). Blood cultures cleared after 48 hours of treatment. Patient able to swallow, eating soft diet, pain controlled. Transitioned to oral clindamycin to complete 14-day course. Educated on warning signs: difficulty breathing, worsening swallowing, high fever, neck stiffness - return to ED immediately. CRITICAL TEACHING: This was life-threatening infection that could have obstructed airway. ENT strongly recommends tonsillectomy in 6-8 weeks once acute infection fully resolved - will prevent recurrence. Without tonsillectomy, 30% chance of another peritonsillar abscess. Patient agrees to surgery. This case demonstrates: (1) Progression from simple pharyngitis to life-threatening abscess, (2) Polymicrobial nature of deep space neck infections requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics, (3) Serious complications including bacteremia, (4) Need for surgical drainage when abscess forms, (5) Importance of follow-up and definitive treatment (tonsillectomy) to prevent recurrence.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Post-tonsillectomy follow-up, 2 weeks after surgery, doing well
procedures_ordered: Tonsillectomy performed 8/22 - bilateral tonsillectomy without complications
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 2 weeks post-tonsillectomy. Surgery performed without complications. Post-op course typical - 7-10 days of throat pain, difficulty swallowing, managed with pain medications and soft diet. Throat now healed, tonsillar fossae well-granulated, no signs of infection or bleeding. Patient back to normal diet, no pain, back to work. Lost 6 lbs during recovery period (expected). This definitive treatment eliminates risk of recurrent peritonsillar abscess. Patient very relieved to have this behind him - was frightening experience with the abscess. Final teaching points: (1) Peritonsillar abscess is serious, potentially life-threatening infection, (2) Early recognition and treatment critical, (3) Don't delay seeking care for severe or worsening sore throat, (4) Polymicrobial infections may require broader antibiotic coverage than simple pharyngitis, (5) Surgical drainage necessary for abscess, (6) Tonsillectomy prevents recurrence in high-risk patients. Complete resolution of case.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing progression from simple pharyngitis to life-threatening peritonsillar abscess
Understanding why initial antibiotic (amoxicillin) failed despite Group A Strep sensitivity
Identifying polymicrobial infection (strep + anaerobe) as cause of treatment failure
Recognizing airway emergency and need for urgent surgical intervention
Understanding complications including bacteremia from deep space infection
Appreciating need for tonsillectomy to prevent recurrence
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize progression from acute pharyngitis to peritonsillar abscess, (2) identify red flag symptoms (trismus, drooling, uvular deviation, muffled voice) indicating abscess formation, (3) understand polymicrobial nature of deep space infections requiring anaerobic coverage, (4) recognize treatment failure despite appropriate initial antibiotic, (5) identify life-threatening complications including airway compromise and bacteremia, (6) understand need for surgical drainage when abscess forms, (7) appreciate role of definitive treatment (tonsillectomy) in preventing recurrence, and (8) recognize this as an ENT emergency requiring immediate specialist involvement. The LLM should flag initial pharyngitis treatment at V1, recognize dramatic worsening and airway emergency at V2, understand polymicrobial infection and bacteremia at V3, identify successful treatment response at V4, and appreciate complete resolution with tonsillectomy at V5. This case emphasizes that seemingly simple throat infections can rapidly progress to life-threatening conditions requiring emergency intervention.

ground_truth_correlations.description: Severe hypertension (BP 220/128) with acute end-organ damage (kidney injury, hypertensive encephalopathy, retinopathy)
Progressive worsening of renal function from baseline CKD to acute kidney injury during hypertensive crisis
Medication non-adherence leading to uncontrolled hypertension and hypertensive emergency
Lost to follow-up for 18 months despite severe hypertension and CKD, lack of medication access

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Follow-up for high blood pressure and kidney disease
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 52 yo African American male with long-standing hypertension and CKD Stage 3b. BP today 168/102 - UNCONTROLLED despite triple therapy. Creatinine 2.1 (baseline ~1.8-2.0), GFR 38. Significant proteinuria. Added hydralazine as fourth agent. Patient admits inconsistent medication adherence - sometimes skips doses, ran out of medications last month and didn't refill for 2 weeks due to cost. Lost insurance 6 months ago, now paying out of pocket. Discussed patient assistance programs. Nephrology referral for CKD management. CRITICAL: Patient at very high risk for cardiovascular events and progression to ESRD. Stressed importance of medication adherence and BP control. RTC 4 weeks.

social_history_updates.food_security: insecure (high sodium diet, fast food frequent)

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: Severe headache, confusion, blurry vision, chest pressure x2 days

started: Nicardipine IV infusion for BP control

new_acute: Acute kidney injury on CKD (N17.9, N18.32)

procedures_ordered: CT head - no acute hemorrhage or infarct, mild cerebral edema
Chest X-ray - cardiomegaly, no pulmonary edema
EKG - LVH with strain pattern, no acute STEMI
Troponin - mildly elevated 0.12 ng/mL (likely demand ischemia)
Fundoscopic exam - bilateral papilledema, flame hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots (Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy)
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: HYPERTENSIVE EMERGENCY - LIFE-THREATENING. 52 yo male presenting with BP 220/128, severe headache, confusion, visual changes, chest pressure. LOST TO FOLLOW-UP for 18 MONTHS since last visit. Patient admits stopped taking ALL blood pressure medications 6 months ago - couldn't afford them, lost insurance, felt 'fine' so didn't think he needed them. Now with ACUTE END-ORGAN DAMAGE: (1) Hypertensive encephalopathy - confusion, severe headache, CT shows cerebral edema, (2) Acute kidney injury - creatinine 3.8 (was 2.1 in Jan 2023), GFR 18 (was 38), now Stage 4 CKD, (3) Hypertensive retinopathy Grade IV - papilledema, hemorrhages, at risk for vision loss, (4) Possible cardiac ischemia - troponin 0.12, chest pressure, EKG shows LVH with strain. Started IV nicardipine for controlled BP reduction - goal to lower MAP by 10-20% in first hour, 25% in first 24 hours (too rapid reduction can cause stroke). ADMITTED TO ICU. This is PREVENTABLE emergency caused by medication non-adherence.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: ICU day 3, BP improving, mental status clearing

new_acute: Acute kidney injury on CKD, improving (N17.9, N18.4)

procedures_ordered: Repeat fundoscopic exam - papilledema improving, hemorrhages stable
Echocardiogram - severe LVH, EF 45% (reduced), diastolic dysfunction
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: ICU day 3. BP controlled with IV nicardipine, now weaning to oral medications. BP down to 168/96 (from 220/128). Mental status completely cleared - patient alert, oriented, no longer confused. Headache resolved. Vision improving but still some blurriness. Creatinine improved from 3.8 to 3.2 but still much worse than baseline 2.1 - now has Stage 4 CKD (was Stage 3b). Some kidney damage may be permanent. Restarted oral antihypertensives at MAXIMUM doses - four-drug regimen. Echo shows severe LVH and reduced EF 45% (hypertensive cardiomyopathy). EXTENSIVE COUNSELING: This was life-threatening, preventable emergency. Could have died or had permanent stroke/blindness/kidney failure. Social work involved - enrolled patient in medication assistance programs, all BP meds now FREE. Helping with insurance enrollment. Patient very shaken by this experience, now understands severity. Transfer to step-down unit, discharge tomorrow if BP stable.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 1-month post-discharge follow-up, adhering to all medications
procedures_ordered: Home BP monitoring log reviewed - BPs 135-155/85-95
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: Excellent 1-month follow-up. Patient 100% adherent to medications (verified with pharmacy records, patient using pill organizer). BP much improved at 142/88 (goal <130/80 but this is significant improvement). Creatinine stabilized at 2.8 (was 3.8 at worst, baseline 2.1). GFR 26 - Stage 4 CKD, likely some permanent kidney damage from hypertensive crisis. Nephrology discussing preparation for eventual dialysis - may need within 1-2 years. Patient lost 6 lbs, quit smoking (3 weeks smoke-free), stopped alcohol, working with dietitian on low-sodium diet. Vision fully recovered. No headaches. Medication assistance programs working well - all meds free. Re-enrolled in Medicaid. Patient attending all appointments. This case demonstrates: (1) Catastrophic consequences of medication non-adherence, (2) Social determinants (insurance, cost) as barriers to care, (3) Hypertensive emergency with multi-organ damage, (4) Some damage (kidney, heart) may be permanent despite treatment, (5) Importance of addressing barriers to medication access, (6) Behavior change after serious health scare. Patient's life was saved but long-term complications remain.

clinical_timeline.chief_complaint: 3-month follow-up, BP well-controlled, preparing for dialysis

started: Erythropoietin injections for anemia of CKD

procedures_ordered: AV fistula placement scheduled for dialysis access
clinical_timeline.provider_note_snippet: 3 months post-hypertensive emergency. Patient doing remarkably well. BP excellent at 136/82 on four-drug regimen. 100% medication adherent. Lost total 17 lbs through diet changes. Smoke-free for 3.5 months. No alcohol. Creatinine stable 3.1, GFR 23 (Stage 4 CKD approaching Stage 5). Nephrology preparing for dialysis - AV fistula surgery scheduled next month, estimated need for dialysis in 6-9 months when GFR <15. Patient has accepted this reality - understands permanent kidney damage from years of uncontrolled hypertension culminating in hypertensive crisis. Started erythropoietin for anemia. On transplant waiting list. This case illustrates: (1) Hypertensive emergency is medical catastrophe with multi-organ damage, (2) Medication non-adherence due to cost/access is major public health issue, (3) Some end-organ damage is irreversible even with subsequent excellent control, (4) Addressing social determinants is critical for long-term management, (5) Near-death experience can be powerful motivator for behavior change, (6) Comprehensive support (medication assistance, insurance, dietitian, social work) improves outcomes. Patient's life was saved but faces dialysis - sobering reminder of consequences of untreated hypertension.

expected_llm_challenges: Recognizing hypertensive emergency vs hypertensive urgency (presence of end-organ damage)
Understanding the progression from uncontrolled hypertension to multi-organ failure
Identifying medication non-adherence as root cause of preventable emergency
Recognizing social determinants (insurance, cost) as barriers to medication access
Understanding irreversible end-organ damage despite subsequent control
Appreciating the role of comprehensive social support in long-term management
evaluation_notes: This case tests ability to: (1) recognize hypertensive emergency (BP >180/120 WITH acute end-organ damage) vs urgency (elevated BP without damage), (2) identify multiple end-organ injuries (brain, kidney, eye, heart), (3) understand medication non-adherence as root cause, (4) recognize 18-month care gap and its consequences, (5) identify social determinants as critical barriers to care, (6) understand that some organ damage is permanent despite later excellent control, (7) track progression from Stage 3b to Stage 4 CKD approaching dialysis, (8) appreciate need for comprehensive support addressing insurance, medication access, and social needs, and (9) understand this as preventable catastrophe. The LLM should flag uncontrolled hypertension and medication non-adherence at V1, identify 18-month gap and recognize life-threatening emergency with multi-organ damage at V2, understand ICU management and partial recovery at V3, track improved control but permanent damage at V4, and recognize long-term consequences (approaching dialysis) despite excellent subsequent adherence at V5. This case emphasizes that hypertension is 'silent killer' until catastrophic complications occur, and addressing social barriers is essential for management.
